title: Double Blind Medium Term Efficacy Study of Trp01 in Patients With Mild to Moderate Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to determine whether tryptophan is effective in the treatment of mild to moderate Alzheimer's Disease (AD).
description_detailed:
The clinical trial will be a double-blind, placebo-controlled study with patients being randomized in a 2:1 ratio into groups A and B, respectively:

Group A: TRP01 1g b.i.d. for 26 weeks

Group B: placebo capsules b.i.d. for 26 weeks

After the initial screening, clinic visits will take place at 0, 13 and 26 weeks. The blinding will be maintained until all patients have completed the 26-week trial. Any patients wishing to continue taking the medication upon completion of the trial will be provided a prescription for the drug and may purchase it at their own expense.
explanation_target: Reason: The study tests TRP01 (tryptophan) for treatment of mild–moderate Alzheimer’s disease and lists cognitive scales (MMSE and ADAS‑Cog) as primary outcome measures, indicating the trial’s primary intent is to evaluate effects on cognition. citeturn1search1.

Act: The interventional regimen is TRP01 1 g twice daily versus placebo for 26 weeks (double‑blind, randomized, 2:1). Primary outcomes are MMSE and ADAS‑Cog; secondary outcomes include Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) among others. These trial details are documented in the public trial record. citeturn1search0turn1search1.

Mechanism/context from literature: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid (small molecule) and precursor to serotonin and other metabolites; tryptophan/its metabolites have been studied for effects on neurotransmission, neuroinflammation, and (in preclinical models) intraneuronal Aβ levels. This biochemistry suggests plausible symptomatic (cognitive/neurotransmitter) effects and possible indirect influences on pathology. citeturn1search6turn1search3.

Reflection / classification decision: The intervention is a small, non‑biologic compound given to improve clinical status with primary cognitive endpoints, not a monoclonal antibody or vaccine aimed explicitly at amyloid/tau. Although preclinical data suggest tryptophan may influence amyloid in animal models, the trial’s design and endpoints indicate the primary goal is symptomatic/cognitive improvement. Therefore the best fit among the provided categories is: cognitive enhancer. citeturn1search1turn1search3turn1search6.

Ambiguity note: Because some preclinical studies report effects of tryptophan or its metabolites on AD pathology, one could argue a disease‑targeting potential; however, the human trial’s stated outcomes and treatment purpose support classification as a cognitive enhancer rather than a disease‑targeted small molecule. References used above: clinical trial registry entry and MedPath trial listing (NCT00202124), a mouse study showing reduced intraneuronal Aβ with high tryptophan diet, and a review of tryptophan metabolism in AD. citeturn1search1turn1search0turn1search3turn1search6.
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational product TRP01 is tryptophan, an essential amino acid and biochemical precursor for serotonin (5-HT) and other tryptophan metabolites; the trial’s primary outcomes are cognitive scales (MMSE, ADAS‑Cog), indicating a symptomatic/cognitive‑enhancing intent rather than an explicit anti‑amyloid or anti‑tau disease‑modifying strategy. citeturn1search0turn0search7

Act: Extracted trial details — TRP01 (tryptophan) 1 g twice daily vs placebo for 26 weeks, randomized double‑blind 2:1, primary outcomes MMSE and ADAS‑Cog — from the public trial record; because tryptophan acts via neurotransmitter synthesis (serotonin pathway) and related neuromodulatory/metabolic routes, the intervention best fits CADRO category D) Neurotransmitter Receptors (agents that alter neurotransmitter systems/synaptic signalling). citeturn1search0turn1search1turn1search3

Reflect: Although preclinical studies report tryptophan or high‑tryptophan diets reduced intraneuronal Aβ and modulated inflammation in AD mouse models (i.e., possible indirect pathology effects), the human trial’s design and endpoints are symptomatic/cognitive — therefore classifying it under neurotransmitter modulation is the most specific CADRO match. If future trials explicitly target amyloid, inflammation, or gut‑brain pathways as primary mechanisms, reclassification could be considered. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search7

Web search results (sources used): 1) ClinicalTrials record / trial summary for NCT00202124 (Double Blind Medium Term Efficacy Study of Trp01 in Patients With Mild to Moderate Alzheimer’s Disease) — trial design, dosing, endpoints. citeturn1search0 2) MedPath/registry mirrors summarizing the same trial entry. citeturn1search1 3) DrugBank listing linking tryptophan to completed AD clinical trials (NCT00202124). citeturn1search3 4) Preclinical study: high‑tryptophan diet reduced intraneuronal Aβ in 3xTg‑AD mice (Aging Cell, 2012). citeturn0search0 5) Recent preclinical study: high‑tryptophan diet alleviated cognitive impairment and neuroinflammation in APP/PS1 mice (2023). citeturn0search1 6) Review on tryptophan metabolism in AD (mechanistic context: 5‑HT, kynurenine, AHR, gut‑brain interactions). citeturn0search7
